description:
Paramormyrops kingsleyae is a species of weakly electric fish belonging to the family Mormyridae, which is commonly known as the elephant-nose fish. It is native to the Congo River basin in central Africa.

This species is characterized by its elongated, eel-like body shape and a distinctive elongated snout or "nose," which is used to detect prey and communicate with other individuals through the use of electric signals. The electric organ discharges (EODs) produced by P. kingsleyae are used for navigation, communication, and prey detection in the murky, dimly-lit waters of its natural habitat.

Paramormyrops kingsleyae is relatively small, typically reaching lengths of around 15-20 centimeters. It feeds primarily on small invertebrates and other aquatic organisms found in the riverine environments of the Congo basin. The species plays a role in the local ecosystem as a predator and as a food source for larger predatory fish.

Conservation-wise, P. kingsleyae is currently listed as Least Concern by the IUCN, as it is widely distributed and does not face any major known threats to its populations at this time. However, continued monitoring and assessment of its status is important given the potential impacts of habitat degradation and other environmental changes in the Congo River basin.
